item.description:
Welcome to volume three of Scrolls, a weekly newsletter for sharing cool stuff from the IndieWeb, Fediverse & Cybersecurity realms.

First, a quick aside to talk about RSS (That‚Äôs right! RSS is not dead yet). I refer to this publication as a ‚Äúnewsletter‚Äù (among other things), which I think for many, evokes the idea of email. But as you have likely discovered by now, this newsletter is not emailed to you. Rather, if you want to subscribe, you must do so with good ol‚Äô fashioned RSS. To that end, I recommend getting (if you don‚Äôt have one already) an RSS client - for your phone, for your desktop, laptop, all the things. If you‚Äôre looking for more info, I‚Äôve written an RSS how-to of sorts that you can read. Once you‚Äôve got one, just drop this url https://shellsharks.com/feeds/scroll-feed.xml into it and you should be good-and-subscribed! RSS is a great tool for curating your internet experience. Now on to it!

IndieWeb

Speaking of your experience on the Internet, I‚Äôve got good news and bad news about the web. First, the bad news - a lot of the web sucks. So what‚Äôs the good news? Well the good news is that there is a burgeoning movement to rewild the Internet, to make it more humane, and let it flourish once more. More on this shortly, but first‚Ä¶

What makes the bad web, ‚Äúbad‚Äù? I mean, have you seen any of these things in your web travels? What about any of this annoying stuff? Run into any pathetic AI slop yet? Bet ya have. The enshittification pandemic of the centralized, corporate web is very real, and suffocatingly inescapable. So much so, that I‚Äôve come across quite a few posts about how individuals are yanking big tech out of their life completely (me too). Some of us have started to see - the bad web is dying, and we gotta get out.

So where can you find the ‚Äúgood web‚Äù? The old web? The human web? The IndieWeb? Welp, you‚Äôve already found it. In fact, you‚Äôre reading it right now! Well, at least one small part of it. No matter what you call it, there are pockets of the Internet full of websites owned by individuals, with novel content, published and wholly owned by those individuals. These sites are unique, they are quirky, they probably have innumerable CSS and HTML markup issues (*cough* this site *cough*), they are expressions of those people, and of our collective humanity. They are where we gather, where we share things more than ~300 characters at a time, and where we can just be free to shout into the void.

The ‚Äúgood web‚Äù isn‚Äôt just one place. The web is a digital archipelago. There is no singular map which can exhaustively take you to every island. Instead, explorers like you and me set sail and find these indie-islets, then curate and share them - with our social networks, our friends, on our own websites, etc‚Ä¶ It‚Äôs up to us to bookmark what we discover, and what we enjoy. Like philipp did when he found a cute li‚Äôl blog that had an ‚Äúart guestbook‚Äù. Another great way to save and share cool things you find is by publishing weekly summaries of links and other stuff. Take a look at these cool examples from Sophie, Joel and Micha≈Ç.

Once we‚Äôve re-wilded the Internet, maybe then we can (as Courtney has done) touch grass once more. Until then, here‚Äôs some neat places I‚Äôve discovered in my own recent web surfin‚Äô. Check ‚Äòem out!‚Ä¶

  • Bobby Hiltz
  • Juha-Matti Santala
  • Beam me out!

Fediverse

The Fediverse, ‚Äòtis a silly place‚Ä¶


For example, I‚Äôve come to understand that this is the average Misskey experience üòÜ

On to a more serious topic‚Ä¶ In the last section, we talked about enshittification, and how it has led to a growing IndieWeb movement. Well chances are, if you‚Äôre on the Fediverse, or considering moving here, it‚Äôs probably also because of that same wave of enshittification . People are leaving the entrenched social silos, and seeking out less-enshittified pastures. This hasn‚Äôt gone without notice by the larger, more-established social networks either. Meta‚Äôs Threads has sorta federated, and now Tumblr is set to join the Fediverse as well. While the incumbent web seeks to catch up, the alternative social networks, the ‚ÄúSocial Web‚Äù, pushes on. For example, Mastodon and Mbin both announced big updates in the past week alone.

To reclaim the Internet, and help the continued development of these platforms, your support is needed. Consider, if you can, helping IFTAS, an independent Federated Trust & Safety organization that provides nonprofit support for volunteer social web content moderators, community managers, administrators and more. There are other ways to support the Fediverse too! Just being an active participant in the various communities is a good start. Consider joining a group via FediGroups.social, contributing to the WeDistribute forum, or attending the upcoming FediForum Unconference!

To close out this section, I wanted to spotlight a few Fedi projects & tools worth checking out!

  • Fedica: A multi-platform social media management tool
  • Radicle: Open source, peer-to-peer code collaboration stack built on Git
  • All the projects that Hong Minhee is responsible for, i.e. Fedify, Hollo, BotKit, LogTape, Yoyak & Hackers Pub - phew!

Cybersecurity

The cyberz was as cyber-ey as ever this past week, and I don‚Äôt mean that in a good way. More like‚Ä¶ ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

Here‚Äôs exhibit A: Security Appliance Vulnerability Bingo (lol!)

But we can‚Äôt spend all our time making fun of security appliance vendors can we? Here‚Äôs this week‚Äôs reading list‚Ä¶

  • The Path of a Packet Through The Linux Kernel
  • Sign up for the ICANN Webinar to Discuss INFERMAL, a Project Focused on Malicious Domain Registrations
  • So cool, very IndieWeb - check out Shostack‚Äôs weekly Appsec Roundup
  • February‚Äôs first designer vulnerability: ‚ÄúwhoAMI‚Äù (courtesy of Datadog Security Labs)
  • Here‚Äôs some cool IndieSec blogs I‚Äôve discovered recently
    • Sea Bass From Space
    • Ariadne‚Äôs Space
    • xssfox
    • Ahmed Sherif
  • The Fediverse is the place to be! So if you‚Äôre here, and in infosec, come hang out with me and other cyber folks at the Infosec.pub. We‚Äôve got weekly threads! üçª
    • Mentorship Monday
    • What are You Working on Wednesday
    • Off-Topic Friday

Finally, a few tools to help you on your journey‚Ä¶

  • Search CTF Writeups: Find and explore CTF solutions and writeups
  • Cert Central: Centralized place to document the abuse of code-signing certificates
  • LOLC2: A collection of C2 frameworks that leverage legitimate services to evade detection

Thanks for reading!

item.title: What's A Home Page?

shark:summary.p: Every website you go to has a home page, the page you land on when you go to that site‚Äôs root domain, i.e. for Shellsharks, when you go to ‚Äúhttps://shellsharks.com‚Äù. Since 2021 my home page has had a very simple design - the logo, some link icons and the classic list of recent posts. In January of 2024 I simplified it even further, rearranging some graphics and removing the icons, filing them away in the site‚Äôs hamburger menu. More recently (~Februrary 2025), I got the itch to start tinkering with the site again and made a few further visual changes to the home page, opening up the feed to all content I write, not just posts, and adding some icons to differentiate the different content types.

item.description:
Every website you go to has a home page, the page you land on when you go to that site‚Äôs root domain, i.e. for Shellsharks, when you go to ‚Äúhttps://shellsharks.com‚Äù. Since 2021 my home page has had a very simple design - the logo, some link icons and the classic list of recent posts. In January of 2024 I simplified it even further, rearranging some graphics and removing the icons, filing them away in the site‚Äôs hamburger menu. More recently (~Februrary 2025), I got the itch to start tinkering with the site again and made a few further visual changes to the home page, opening up the feed to all content I write, not just posts, and adding some icons to differentiate the different content types.

But, it still just wasn‚Äôt what I was looking for. I knew I wanted something else, but wasn‚Äôt sure what that something else is. So I went looking for inspiration. I found that in two of my favorite sites, Cory Dransfeldt & Flamed Fury. Cory‚Äôs design has both a simplicity and cleanness to it, but also neatly showcases what he‚Äôs got goin‚Äô on across the site. I really enjoy his use of color as well. fLaMEd has an incredible home page splash graphic and an amazingly curated collection of stuff, made available right there on the home page. So I took some of their ideas, and shellsharks-ified them, incorporating those ideas into what is (for now) my new home page, behold!

As I was building the new home page (and as I continue to do so), I‚Äôve asked myself, ‚Äúwhat is a home page?‚Äù What is it meant to do? What should it look like? What feeling do I want people to have when they go there? Where do I want them to go once they‚Äôre on my site? What do I want them to read? What‚Äôs important to me or to my readers? How do I want to use my site? The home page is a collection of opportunities and doors. My old home page was simple yes, and that was visually striking in a way that I‚Äôve always enjoyed, but it didn‚Äôt tell you much, and what it did show you, was pretty limited - just a list of stuff I had published recently. There was no story, and it effectively hid a lot of the other things on my site that you, the reader, might be interested in, stuff I am proud of. So the idea behind the redesign was to surface these things, introduce you to my site, showcase what I‚Äôve done recently and what I think you might want to see. I have a lot to offer, and have put in a lot of work, but only the real shellsharks spelunkers could have ever found it, digging around through the cavernous hamburger menu and web of hyperlinks throughout the site.

It‚Äôs a work in progress, my site always is, IndieWeb sites just tend to be. That‚Äôs what‚Äôs fun! What‚Äôs great about this particular modular design is that I‚Äôm able to add new things, showcase more stuff when I feel like it. One big downside to the classic design (circa 2021) was that I never featured anything but my formal ‚Äúblog posts‚Äù. I talk about why I didn‚Äôt like that here. So I opened up the feed to everything, which introduced a new issue. Now, my best content was at risk of being buried in a way that I felt was a disservice. For example, I have a new Link Log where I share cool sites/blogs that I find, and I added those links to that home feed. But, I wasn‚Äôt incentivized to share a lot of links, because then my home page feed would‚Äôve been overrun with just links to other people‚Äôs stuff (cool as that stuff may be), effectively watering down my site to a degree and de-emphasizing all the other stuff on my site. The new design allows me to share as many links as I want, without overshadowing everything else. Awesome!

So yeah, the new home page is live, and I think it‚Äôs great. I‚Äôd love to hear about your home page, or home pages of sites that you love (so I can get more inspo), or thoughts that you have about my new home page, hit me up anytime!

(Also, I‚Äôve kept my classic home page available as the ‚Äúhome feed‚Äù.)

item.title: Mastodon.social is fine

shark:summary.p: As others have said, Mastodon.social is fine, you have not screwed up. Are there some downsides to Mastodon.social? Sure, but that goes with any server, or any platform or any choice you make in life (haha). Some folks on Mastodon (or the Fediverse at large) deride Mastodon for A. being ‚Äútoo big‚Äù/centralized, B. not liking their moderation practices, C. their association with efforts such as Meta‚Äôs Threads federating, and/or D. certain accounts they have that folks may not like elsewhere. Whatever. Mastodon.social is FREE to join, is obviously widely federated - which helps with reach and search, and since it is the flagship instance, has decent moderation, good support, bleeding-edge features, etc..

Some folks on Mastodon (or the Fediverse at large) deride Mastodon for A. being ‚Äútoo big‚Äù/centralized, B. not liking their moderation practices, C. their association with efforts such as Meta‚Äôs Threads federating, and/or D. certain accounts they have that folks may not like elsewhere. Whatever. Mastodon.social is FREE to join, is obviously widely federated - which helps with reach and search, and since it is the flagship instance, has decent moderation, good support, bleeding-edge features, etc..

Also, as others have said, you can migrate your followers elsewhere later if you decide you want a smaller instance, or don‚Äôt like mastodon.social for some reason, etc.. The only caveat is right now you can‚Äôt also migrate your posts, but I personally don‚Äôt see that as being a big deal. If you care about things you post over there, you can download a post archive, or maybe just archive your good stuff on a personal blog or something.

I have an account on Mastodon.social, an account on a secondary (much smaller instance) and a self-hosted instance (yeah I know, I have a problem). There are pros and cons to each experience. What‚Äôs important is that you made it out (of the centralized platforms) and are building a presence on the open, federated, social web. Congrats! You can also ask for help there using hashtags like (#fedihelp, #askfedi) and you‚Äôll be sure to get lots of responses.

item.title: Tapestry Has Found its Place

shark:summary.p: A few days ago I confidently stated that ‚Äúunified timelines are not for me‚Äù, but I think I may have been a bit too hasty in that declaration. I‚Äôve been tinkering around with Tapestry for a few days now, trying to find a way to fit it into my daily feed ingestion workflow and I think I‚Äôm starting to discover its niche for me. This doesn‚Äôt really change what I said in that previous post, Tapestry is not a good (main) RSS reader, especially (again) when you weave together RSS feeds and social timelines (for the reasons I state in the article). Secondarily, Tapestry isn‚Äôt a great RSS reader (right now) as it struggles mightily when faced with simultaneously updating 100‚Äôs of disparate feeds, which my current RSS app (Reeder) does without breaking a sweat. In time, that performance issue may improve, but the former issue won‚Äôt. But let‚Äôs not dwell on what I don‚Äôt use Tapestry for, let‚Äôs instead talk about what I think it can be good at, and what I‚Äôve started using it for over the past couple days.

item.description:
A few days ago I confidently stated that ‚Äúunified timelines are not for me‚Äù, but I think I may have been a bit too hasty in that declaration. I‚Äôve been tinkering around with Tapestry for a few days now, trying to find a way to fit it into my daily feed ingestion workflow and I think I‚Äôm starting to discover its niche for me. This doesn‚Äôt really change what I said in that previous post, Tapestry is not a good (main) RSS reader, especially (again) when you weave together RSS feeds and social timelines (for the reasons I state in the article). Secondarily, Tapestry isn‚Äôt a great RSS reader (right now) as it struggles mightily when faced with simultaneously updating 100‚Äôs of disparate feeds, which my current RSS app (Reeder) does without breaking a sweat. In time, that performance issue may improve, but the former issue won‚Äôt. But let‚Äôs not dwell on what I don‚Äôt use Tapestry for, let‚Äôs instead talk about what I think it can be good at, and what I‚Äôve started using it for over the past couple days.

I spent a long while yammering on about signal-to-noise ratio and fidelity as it relates to my ‚Äúfeeds‚Äù last time I wrote about unified timelines. There, I made the case for why mushing together my RSS feeds with (as an example) a social feed didn‚Äôt make sense, and I stand by that. I want to keep my RSS feeds in an RSS app, because they are the ‚Äúhighest-fidelity‚Äù feed and shouldn‚Äôt be paired with mid or low-fidelity-type feeds. Similarly. my Mastodon/Fediverse feeds need to be kept in their own app. But what about everything else? Here‚Äôs where Tapestry has found it‚Äôs niche for me.

You see when it comes to RSS, I scroll through & consider every post in that feed. It is highly curated afterall and there‚Äôs a decent likelihood im interested in anything/everything that shows up there. For my Fedi feeds, they are also highly curated, but more prone to ‚Ä¶ let‚Äôs call it ‚Äúsilliness‚Äù, so I tend to scroll a bit faster through that feed and don‚Äôt necessarily stop to really read and consider each post. After that what is there? There are a collection of ‚Äúfeeds‚Äù that I will, only look at occasionally, are high volume / low signal-to-noise, or are *‚Äúdiscovery-oriented‚Äù, in which I mean things I peruse to discover new stuff that might be of interest to me. This is the third degree of fidelity, and for those odd collection of feeds, Tapestry is actually quite a nice vehicle to consume them.

Feed Fidelity Continuum
  • Tier 1: RSS
  • Tier 2: Mastodon / Fediverse (non-algorithmic social feeds)
  • Tier 3: Other (e.g. Bluesky, Reddit, Discovery RSS*, Lemmy/Thrediverse, etc‚Ä¶)

Let‚Äôs talk about what makes Tapestry a great reader/timeline app for these ‚Äòlow-fidelity‚Äô (Tier 3) feeds.

First, (before talking about the things Tapestry is great at) I want to reiterate that in my usage of Tapestry, it really struggled to import and then consistently refresh a large volume of RSS feeds. At first, I tried to import close to 2500 feeds into Tapestry and it simply would not do it. After that, I pared down the list and finally got about 500 feeds imported. The app would skitter and completely time out trying to refresh all those feeds. Contrast that with my Reeder app, purpose-built for RSS, which can ingest and handle 1000‚Äôs of feeds with no issue. So, if you have a high volume of RSS feeds, Tapesty isn‚Äôt for you right now, especially as a pure RSS app (not considering the issues I talked about before in terms of unifying RSS and other types of feeds.)

For social feeds, especially those that you want to actually engage with, Tapestry also isn‚Äôt ideal, as you completely lose all those capabilities to natively like/heart, reply, boost/repost, etc‚Ä¶ You need to bounce out of the Tapestry app into the respective app/client for that social platform to do those things. But! What if you had a social feed that you wanted to follow, but wasn‚Äôt something you engaged with frequently. Then, Tapestry might work pretty well for that. This is the case for me with Bluesky. I have a Bluesky account, and I follow some folks there that do not have presences elsewhere. Because I want to see what they have to say, and I want to limit the amount of time I spend ‚Äúengaging‚Äù there, Tapestry is a great place for me to mostly-read-only-mode my Bluesky feed. On the rare occasion I see something I really want to interact with on Bluesky, it‚Äôs easy enough to bounce out and do that. This is equally true for pretty much all the feeds I have loaded into Tapestry, it is entirely made up of things that I might want to quickly peruse, but probably won‚Äôt want to engage with.

Scrolling through gobs of stuff that might include something I‚Äôm interested in can be, at times, not the most enjoyable or worthwile scroll. But, Tapestry softens the blow because the app is gorgeous.

Looking back at my fidelity tiers, you‚Äôve got RSS at 1, Fedi at 2, and everything else at 3. From a client perspective, this makes tier 1 and tier 2 pretty simple/obvious. You have an RSS app for 1 and a Fedi client (that supports more than just Mastodon) for 2. But for the third tier, ‚ÄúOther‚Äù, you need something that can natively ingest a wide variety of feeds, some of which may be kinda niche. Tapestry is not only built to do this out-of-the-box (as it is a unified timeline app), but it also ships with a powerful, extendable, connectors system by which you can load in (or develop your own) third-party connectors. This will make browsing feeds from all over the place uniquely possible.

In this story, Tapestry is being used to ingest, weave-together and view a wide variety of eclectic feeds, all of which are ‚Äúlower signal-to-noise‚Äù. This could mean the timeline balloons beyond what you may feel like scrolling through on any given day. To help handle the firehose, Tapestry also ships with a powerful set of features for muffling, muting and building custom timelines.

So, that‚Äôs how I‚Äôve been using Tapestry. It looks great, performs well for what I am now using it for and has even earned a coveted spot on my phone home screen. I‚Äôve also seen a number of connectors being shared by the community too to further extend its capabilities which is awesome! Let me know what you think though! Especially for those of you who agreed with my original assessment. Do you think Tapestry (or other unified timeline apps) could have a place in your workflow? Or are you a normal person and don‚Äôt feel the need to keep up with every feed that‚Äôs of even mild interest to you?

item.title: Saying it again: Someone will read your blog

shark:summary.p: @sol2070 I‚Äôve seen a few posts like this pop up in the last few weeks, all with similar theme, e.g. ‚Äúno one reads your blog but you should do it anyways‚Äù. I agree, in part - at least with the fact that you should blog, whether anyone reads or not. But the fact is, people DO read your blog, they will stumble across it, and given the scale of the Internet, of the world, you do have an audience, no matter how niche what you have to say is. I talk about that here.

item.description:
@sol2070 I‚Äôve seen a few posts like this pop up in the last few weeks, all with similar theme, e.g. ‚Äúno one reads your blog but you should do it anyways‚Äù. I agree, in part - at least with the fact that you should blog, whether anyone reads or not. But the fact is, people DO read your blog, they will stumble across it, and given the scale of the Internet, of the world, you do have an audience, no matter how niche what you have to say is. I talk about that here.

I get it, I used to have the same thoughts when I started. ‚ÄúNo one will read this, but I‚Äôll do it for myself‚Äù. That‚Äôs fine, but I‚Äôve learned that it just isn‚Äôt true, and becoming less true by the day. More people want the IndieWeb, a return to the more authentic web. Your silly ‚Äúblog‚Äù is where people increasingly want to go. So blog for yourself, sure. But blog for everyone out there who, right now, is looking to find something real, some human connection, something that isn‚Äôt AI slop, blog for them.

And if that ain‚Äôt enough, consider blogging for these reasons.

item.title: Scroll duo

shark:summary.p: Welcome to volumen duo of Scrolls, a newsletter for sharing cool stuff from the IndieWeb, Fediverse & Cybersecurity realms.

item.description:
Welcome to volumen duo of Scrolls, a newsletter for sharing cool stuff from the IndieWeb, Fediverse & Cybersecurity realms.

I‚Äôve decided to plan the regular issuance of this publication for Fridays instead of Sundays. It‚Äôs easier for me to get it out the door with this schedule. This means your getting this issue 2 days sooner than ya thought and only ~3 days after I put out the last one. Lucky you! Now on to it‚Ä¶

IndieWeb

I have a site, you‚Äôre on it! Sometimes I look at it, and I don‚Äôt like what I see, or I see other sites and wish mine looked a bit more like those. Ultimately though, I find peace, because in the IndieWeb world, it‚Äôs good to be unique, just be yourself.

That said, it‚Äôs great to learn, fun to build, and perfectly acceptable to be inspired by what you see elsewhere on the web. If you‚Äôre just getting started, you may be interested in joining an IndieWeb community, a website club or even starting your own ‚Äúblog club‚Äù, because y‚Äôknow, making a website can be hard, and there are a few things you might not want to do on your site-building journey. But don‚Äôt stress, you learn by doing and there‚Äôs soooo many fun things to do. You could build a link blog, or build a photoroll, or build (and then later destroy) a Likes feed. If nothing else, you could just blog for the hell of it, it doesn‚Äôt need to be great, just let the catharsis flow. But if you gotta have something, why not try this weekly blogging challenge. (That‚Äôs what I did)

Music Questions Challenge

  1. What are five of your favorite albums?
  2. What are five of your favorite songs?
  3. Favorite Instrument(s)?
  4. What song or album are you current listening to?
  5. Do you listen to the radio? If so, how often?
  6. How often do you listen to music?
  7. How often do you discover music? And how do you discover music?
  8. What‚Äôs a song or album that you enjoy that you wish had more recognition?
  9. What‚Äôs your favourite song of all time?
  10. Has your taste in music evolved over the years?

Since I‚Äôve already mentioned inspiration, let‚Äôs talk about discovery a bit. Yes, search engines are worse than they‚Äôve ever been, and the actually-traveled web seems more centralized than ever, but we know the IndieWeb exists. It‚Äôs just a matter of finding these digital gardens, and once you do, saving and subscribing when you find something you like. Tapestry is the newest addition to the rich and growing collection of feed aggregation apps that we have available to us. It might not be for you, but you should check it out and see! As for finding stuff, try out Minifeed.net, BUKMARK.CLUB, smallweb.cc or Blue Pages for roaming the Indie and Old-webz. Some of my favorite things I‚Äôve stumbled across this week include Combatting doomscroll (from L. Rhodes) & Tracy Durnell‚Äôs Mind Garden, check‚Äôm out!

Fediverse

Nope, it‚Äôs not just you. The Fediverse is very active right now, and there‚Äôs a lot of enthusiasm and energy across the network, being poured into all manner of projects.

Frequency (currently in beta) is a Fediverse-compatible, photo-forward app which emphasizes privacy and non-algorithmic control. There‚Äôs even a Fediverse server built using NNTP of all things! Castopod is looking to show out with some tips for monetizing using their platform - OK, get it! But the big story this week is probably Reddit‚Äôs continued enshitti-slide (sub banning), resulting in a surge of interest for Threadiverse platforms, sought after for their well‚Ä¶ this exact kinda nonsense resiliency. So, might I recommend infosec.pub for my tech/infosec folks? Oh and Reddit isn‚Äôt the only centralized platform people are avoiding (*cough* Discord *cough*), NodeBB has federated and is making a statement as well.

But it‚Äôs not just new apps and platform stuff, there‚Äôs a lot of connective tissue and Fedi-supporting services that are being developed as well, each enhancing and pushing the Fediverse forward. Improvements across verification, moderation & reach all saw movement this week. One such organization, that is trying to push things forward, is Spritely, who‚Äôs mission is literally to ‚Äúadvance networked user freedom‚Äù, and they‚Äôre looking for your support!

News aside, are you looking to improve your Fediverse-roving experience? In a non-algorithmic world, we‚Äôre responsible for self-curating our feeds, so start with following some more folks! Are you technically on Mastodon, but really haven‚Äôt quite figured it out yet? How about reading THE COUNTERFORCE GUIDE TO MASTODON AND THE FEDIVERSE (FOR PUNKS!). The recently minted Fedi Forum also seems like a great way to help, and be helped, and is unsurprisingly Fedi-native! Do you live in or near Austin, Texas? Love the Fediverse? Well Flipboard is hosting the ‚ÄúFediverse House‚Äù to talk about and showcase the social web in all its awesomeness. Not a boring day in the decentralized web is there?

Cybersecurity

Alright cyber-frienz, here‚Äôs some stuff for you too.

  • @kpwn announced some updates to CVE Crowd, a crowd-sourced vulnerability intelligence platform
  • watchTowr Labs dropped an absolutely bonkers, and wildly detailed, supply chain security writeup
  • PortSwigger publishes their annual top 10 web hacking techniques
  • Google thinks they‚Äôve almost completely eliminated exploitable web vulnerabilities (lol)
  • Ah, CVSS is the latest topic of discussion. Some say we need it, others‚Ä¶ want it to die
  • Got some interesting research you‚Äôre sitting on? Why not submit to OWASP Global AppSec USA or fwd: cloudsec North America?
  • Maybe that research can help someone not end up on this list
  • Looking for more juicy intel and security shtuff? I recommend following @screaminggoat on Mastodon
  • Check out the exploits.club Weekly Newsletter
  • Here‚Äôs an oldie but goodie asking ‚ÄúWhat is security?‚Äù
  • Finally, here‚Äôs a pair of cool infosec blogs I discovered this week - B‚ÄôAD Samurai & Blas

Thanks for reading!

item.title: What To Add To Your Site First

shark:summary.p:
You got yourself a domain, you found a place to host your site, it‚Äôs up and running! Now what?
There‚Äôs A LOT you can do with a website. I mean you can pretty much do anything y‚Äôknow? But here‚Äôs what I recommend you do first, before anything else.

item.description:
You got yourself a domain, you found a place to host your site, it‚Äôs up and running! Now what?

There‚Äôs A LOT you can do with a website. I mean you can pretty much do anything y‚Äôknow? But here‚Äôs what I recommend you do first, before anything else.

  1. Put some sort of contact information on your site, maybe even on your home page. This contact info could be an email, or a social media handle. It‚Äôs nice for people to be able to message you about your site!

  2. Create an ‚ÄúAbout‚Äù page (preferably at https://YOURSITE/about). Here you can just briefly tell anyone who‚Äôs stumbled across your site who you are, and what the site is for. Easy!

  3. For participating, or opting out of, broader web stuff, you might want to create a sitemap and/or a robots.txt file. The sitemap helps inform search engine crawlers what on your site you want indexed. Conversely, you‚Äôll want the robots.txt file to instruct those same crawlers what pages they should avoid.

  4. Though it isn‚Äôt required, I would suggest creating a ‚Äúblog‚Äù too, where you can publish stuff you want to write about/share with any current/future readership. If you do decide to blog, be sure to also create an RSS feed so that people can subscribe to your content!

  5. As a bonus, I would lastly suggest having some sort of search capability natively on your site. Search engines are becoming ever-more unreliable, so having a way to natively find things you‚Äôve said/posted in the past is super useful!

Other stuff you can do with your site

item.title: Unified Timelines Are Not For Me

shark:summary.p: Several unified, social-web-forward, chronological timeline apps have popped up recently. Notably Reeder (not to be confused with Reeder Classic), Tapestry & Surf. Though these apps differ in many ways, they have these core commonalities‚Ä¶

item.description:
Several unified, social-web-forward, chronological timeline apps have popped up recently. Notably Reeder (not to be confused with Reeder Classic), Tapestry & Surf. Though these apps differ in many ways, they have these core commonalities‚Ä¶

  1. They support mixed-content/heterogenous feeds (e.g. podcasts, YouTube, Mastodon, Pixelfed, Bluesky, Glass, Flickr, Reddit, RSS, Tumblr and more)
  2. All feeds are woven together in a unified, chronological timeline with some form of timeline sync rather than unread counts typical of your classic RSS feed readers
  3. They also support the ability to create custom feeds, timelines and filters

Cool right? This sounds useful. I can reduce the amount of apps I‚Äôm opening all the time and do a better job not missing things, yeah? In theory. But in practice, I have found that these apps, cool as they are, just don‚Äôt give me what I want and need. Let me explain why‚Ä¶

Curation & completionism: RSS feeds are highly curated and high fidelity/signal-to-noise. What I mean by that, is you subscribe to what you want, and you get nothing else. I also think that generally, people‚Äôs list of RSS feeds is smaller and more highly curated than their social media follows (as an example). Non-algorithmic social feeds (i.e. Mastodon / Fediverse platforms) are still (generally) highly curated (at least for me), but lower signal-to-noise courtesy of the nature of social media/micro-blogging. You get a lot more casual posts, short-form stuff, shitposts, and of course boosts/reposts, all of which add more noise to the feed. This means that when juxtaposed in a unified timeline, you lose the fidelity of your RSS feeds, by combining it with the higher noise feed of your social media timeline. You continue to lose fidelity as you add even noisier feeds (i.e. Reddit, Tumblr, or algorithmic timelines).

Social functionality: When you scroll a social feed, there are a lot of little interactions you may want to perform. Namely ‚Äústars‚Äù and ‚Äúboosts‚Äù (to use the Mastodon lexicon). In order to do those things while browsing a unified feed app however, you would have to jump out of the unified timeline/app into the respective app, which adds a lot of overhead, especially if you‚Äôre someone like me who tends to like/repost a lot of stuff. You may also want to follow an account, mute something, search for something in-app, add something to a list, etc‚Ä¶ There‚Äôs lots of functionality you just lose by not being in the app that supports the actual service you‚Äôre browsing.

Volumetric imbalance: I touched on this earlier. Let‚Äôs say you don‚Äôt open your RSS app for a day, depending on how many feeds you have subscribed to, you‚Äôll get maybe 10‚Äôs of new items. In a social media app though? Hundreds. When combined in a unified timeline, blog posts, which again are meant to be kinda higher signal, are drowned in a sea of microblog shitposts. Similar story with something like Reddit.

Mindset: Do you really want to browse Reddit threads at the same time you‚Äôre catching up on the blogs you subscribe to? Do you want to scroll through people‚Äôs social media shitposts at the same time you‚Äôre seeing what new podcasts there are? This is of course very subjective, but there‚Äôs something to it. I think I just tend to be a in mood for a particular type of content, and by mushing them all together, it‚Äôs a bit of a rollercoaster.

Now these unified timeline apps do have the ability to switch your feed/custom timeline view, but how does that then work with the timeline sync? If I switch from the unified view to just scroll through my latest YouTube items, what happens when I re-enable the unified timeline at a point in time further back then I had made it in my filtered YT timeline? Are those repopulated in the universal timeline and I have to scroll past them again? Are they intelligently filtered out? It gets a bit complicated.

Native functionality: In a unified timeline app, you just lose out on native functionality of the client or the overall platform. For Mastodon, you can‚Äôt like, boost, or comment. For Bluesky, you can‚Äôt leverage the algorithmic feed or see notifications. For Reddit, you can‚Äôt browse other non-subscribed subreddits, look at messages, etc‚Ä¶ You get a watered down experience of all these services.

This said, one way to use a unified timeline app in partnership with a native client would be to scroll through the unified timeline, save/bookmark things you want to interact with, and then go through your saves and systematically interact as you had wanted, and then unsave/unbookmark as you complete each interaction. This could probably work for me, but the problem remains that I just tend to scroll faster through a social feed than I would my blog feed. This goes back to the curation/signal problem. How much do you care about each individual feed. You‚Äôre probably perfectly willing to miss something in a Reddit sub, but less willing to miss something in your RSS feed or even Mastodon/Fediverse feed.

Another way I suppose I could use an app like this is to not used the unified timeline at all, but since all my feeds are supported in-app, I can just scroll each individual feed independently, yet all through the same app. But if I‚Äôm doing that, why not just jump into the apps themselves where I don‚Äôt lose functionality? Any time I save by staying in one app, I lose because I‚Äôll likely need to jump out of the universal timeline app to interact with things in the respective native apps.

I really want to like these apps (In fact, I was a Project Tapestry Kickstarter supporter), and I think an app like Surf stands out because it not only has unified timeline stuff, but it has real powerful search and discovery functionality. Don‚Äôt get me wrong, these apps look great (Tapestry is BEAUTIFUL), but they just aren‚Äôt for me - not for the way I use and browse my feeds on a daily basis. To be fair it‚Äôs early days for these apps, and I suspect a lot of new functionality will be added over time. So I will keep my eye on them and continue trying them out as they evolve!

So I still encourage you to just get an RSS app, but hey, I‚Äôm interested in hearing your story about how this does work for ya. It might not be my cup of tea (yet), but that doesn‚Äôt mean it won‚Äôt be yours!

Other Stuff

  • Using Tapestry or Reeder as a Bluesky app is actually a pretty good idea since it gives you one really awesome feature that you can‚Äôt get with the native app - timeline position sync.

item.title: Web Page Annoyances

shark:summary.p: Came across this great post on rachelbythebay.com titled, Web page annoyances that I don't inflict on you here and it got me thinking, does my site avoid all these annoying things? Are there other annoying things that I encounter on the web that my site doesn‚Äôt do? Are there, *gulp*, things my site does that are annoying?

item.description:
Came across this great post on rachelbythebay.com titled, Web page annoyances that I don't inflict on you here and it got me thinking, does my site avoid all these annoying things? Are there other annoying things that I encounter on the web that my site doesn‚Äôt do? Are there, *gulp*, things my site does that are annoying?

DISCLAIMER: I've stolen some of the things from Rachel's list and added them to my own. All credit to her for this amazing original rant though!

Annoying things my site doesn‚Äôt do

I don‚Äôt track engagement in any way. No click counter, no Google analytics, nada. Honestly, I‚Äôm just not interested in it. My site isn‚Äôt monetized, and I don‚Äôt want to obsess over what pieces do well or how many people clicked, or are subscribed, or w/e. I write because it‚Äôs fun and I enjoy engaging with those who message me about something I‚Äôve written. Easy.

I don‚Äôt have ads of any kind. Again, I don‚Äôt monetize the site. My site is first and foremost a resource for myself. To junk it up with a bunch of ads would be counter to this mission. I‚Äôll never have ads. That simple.

I don‚Äôt set cookies. So I have no GDPR-induced privacy pop-up you have to accept or any other cookie-related advisory notices. I actually value your privacy, and do so by not wanting to know anything about you. That is unless you want to reach out to me and chat! Then I‚Äôd love to get to know ya üòÑ.

I don‚Äôt track IPs. My site is hosted off GitHub Pages, and as such, I can‚Äôt even get this information. Even if I could though, I wouldn‚Äôt look at server logs because I just don‚Äôt care.

I don‚Äôt do popups. You won‚Äôt have to make any privacy concessions, nothing is going to pop up and ask you to give me money or subscribe, you can just scroll and click in peace.

I don‚Äôt abuse animations. I actually do have a few things animated within my site. There‚Äôs one page (I won‚Äôt tell you which), where the sharks in my footer will circle when you hover over them. I also have a small few indieweb-related sites that have some 88x31 oldweb-style buttons, some of which animate. Oh, and yeah, my title image has a blinking underscore, but that‚Äôs cool right?

I don‚Äôt have any autoplaying audio or video. Actually, don‚Äôt think I have any audio or video at all. Problem solved.

I don‚Äôt try to ‚Äúgrab you‚Äù when you back out of a page, saying something like ‚Äúbefore you go, check out this other thing‚Äù. That‚Äôd be really annoying.

I don‚Äôt hide or otherwise not include publish dates for blogs. In fact, I have ‚Äòpublished‚Äô and ‚Äòupdated‚Äô dates for all my content.

I don‚Äôt have elements which follow you down the page as you scroll.

I don‚Äôt have any content across pages which begs you to support me or follow me or subscribe or w/e.

I do no scroll-hijacking or tamper with how your browser has implemented scrolling. No silly ‚Äúprogress bar‚Äù which animates as you scroll up and down a page.

I don‚Äôt junk up my pages with icons that claim to be for ‚Äúsharing‚Äù or ‚Äúliking‚Äù a post.

I don‚Äôt do any dynamic page loading as you scroll down. I don‚Äôt have pages with infinite scroll. The page you wanted to see is what you see, nothing else. I have very reasonable pagination for my various post streams.

I don‚Äôt put vacuous and misleading clickbait ‚Äúyou may be interested in‚Ä¶‚Äù boxes at the bottom of my posts.

My site is not monetized, so I don‚Äôt make any money just because you go anywhere on my site.

I don‚Äôt have anything like that annoying Substack page that asks you to subscribe before redirecting you to the actual page you wanted to see.

I don‚Äôt not have a dark mode theme.

I don‚Äôt not have an RSS feed.

Nothing on my site will ask you to enable notifications in your browser, I don‚Äôt ask to send you notifications of any kind. My site doesn‚Äôt need your email.

I don‚Äôt ask for your location.

I don‚Äôt shift things on your screen annoyingly, causing you to mis-click links.

I don‚Äôt muddy my content pages with comments, or awful Disqus forums.

I don‚Äôt ask you to make an account of any kind.

I don‚Äôt have any paywalled or account-walled content.

I don‚Äôt optimize for SEO. Not saying I won‚Äôt try a fun, slightly click-baitey post title every once in a while, but it‚Äôs certainly not done to get better search rankings.

I don‚Äôt have gobs of third-party dependencies. What third-parties I do use I try to expose here.

I don‚Äôt have any janky photo carousels. In fact I keep photos sorta to a minimum on the site.

I don‚Äôt aggressively limit column width for content on large displays. If you got a beautiful, glorious, gigantic, wide-screen monitor and for some unearthly reason wanted to open my site in full-screen mode, you‚Äôll have SUPER wide content to enjoy.

I don‚Äôt do relative dates for posts. It‚Äôs all about them absolute dates. No date math required!

I don‚Äôt have any huge banners or images on content pages. I have some larger graphics like my home page logo, but even that is relatively tame.

I don‚Äôt hide my contact information. Wanna find me on the web? It‚Äôs all pretty easy to find.

Annoying things I (unfortunately?) do

Some things I do on my site you might actually find kinda annoying. Sorry about that. I‚Äôd like to find a way to stop doing those things or mitigate them to an extent in the future‚Ä¶

I do kinda require JavaScript for the site to look normal. Technically you can read posts without JS‚Ä¶but some stuff will certainly be wonky. One day I‚Äôd like to look into how I can make my site play nicely for those with JS tunred off‚Ä¶

I do have all sorts of images without ALTs. In fact, I have a lot of accessibility stuff I desperately need to put time into fixing. Sorry!

I do load some things from other origins (Pictures, some scripts, etc‚Ä¶). You can read about those suppliers here.

What are some other annoying things websites do? Does my site do them? Feel free to let me know, I probably want to fix it, and have it not do that thing. Thanks!

item.title: Scroll ≈´nus

shark:summary.p: Welcome all to the first issue of Scrolls, a newsletter-ish type thing that I hope to compile each week with all sorts of stuff from across the IndieWeb / Fediverse / Cybersecurity realms. The name ‚ÄúScrolls‚Äù is, as you may have already gathered, a play on a piece of writing, the scrolling we do across our various feeds/sites, and the general magic of the web. Enjoy!

item.description:
Welcome all to the first issue of Scrolls, a newsletter-ish type thing that I hope to compile each week with all sorts of stuff from across the IndieWeb / Fediverse / Cybersecurity realms. The name ‚ÄúScrolls‚Äù is, as you may have already gathered, a play on a piece of writing, the scrolling we do across our various feeds/sites, and the general magic of the web. Enjoy!

In the future, I foresee this being published out on Sunday night, but as things go, I was a bit late. Ah well!

First, shoutout to Micha≈Ç Rostocki for this sweet animation. I came across it in my Fedi timeline and it seemed quite appropriate for the occasion!

Also, mms with the equally timely question about IndieWeb newsletters üòÑ.

Let‚Äôs jump in!

IndieWeb

First, some quick commentary on the differentiation (or lack there of) between the ‚ÄúIndieWeb‚Äù, the ‚ÄúSocial Web‚Äù and the Web itself. Put simply‚Ä¶

The Social Web Is The Web

Alright, let‚Äôs talk about getting started with the IndieWeb. (You may first want to read about what the IndieWeb is. IndieWeb.org or my own primer on the IndieWeb maybe be good places to start). Once you‚Äôre caught up, Unplatform‚Äôs guide for escaping social media (and joining the indie web.) looks like a good place to head next! Ok, so you‚Äôre interested now, but how can you actually get started? I‚Äôve long maintained a list of IndieWeb site hosting providers you could peruse, and I encourage you do so. But if it looks like too many options, you could do a lot worse then to check out omg.lol. This is an amazing place to get started not only with a site of your own, but also with many other IndieWeb-esque services (e.g. Fediverse handle, custom Email, etc‚Ä¶)

Looking for one last kick to convince you to get a website of your own? Maybe Dan can convince ya‚Ä¶

Alright cool, stop reading this now, go get yourself a custom domain name and a web hosting provider and meet me back here.

‚Ä¶

‚Ä¶

You‚Äôre back! Nice. You got yourself a site, or at least you have some of the building blocks for one. Now what? Let‚Äôs get into some of the more mechanical bits, i.e. hosting and building your site. If you‚Äôre still stuck on hosting, but interested in a little DIY, check out 32x33 Institute‚Äôs series on hosting your own stuff. Next, you‚Äôll probably want to learn a bit of HTML. If you‚Äôre at this point and start thinking ‚Äúthis just seems way too over my head, I‚Äôm not a web developer or anything sheesh!‚Äù, go check out this guide on how to build a website. This guide was literally built by someone much like yourself I suspect. Not a super developer or coding wiz, just someone who got interested and jumped in to figure it all out - and is now paying it forward with their own guide(s) on how to do exactly what they did. Let it inspire you! If you‚Äôre like me, and you want to use a Static Site Generator, here‚Äôs a podcast episde you may find interesting. Or maybe you already have a site, but yuck, it‚Äôs on Wordpress, here‚Äôs where you can go next. Finally, Stefan Bohacek also has a pretty great resource pack for getting into the IndieWeb.

OK. Your site is up. But‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs looking a little empty. Or plain. Or boring. Let‚Äôs spruce it up! Typically, when I‚Äôm looking for inspiration for what to do with my site, or what to write about, I look at others right in the IndieWeb community. So here, let me showcase some cool stuff I‚Äôve encountered, which may give you some ideas for what to do with your own site!

  • How about building a page for you to archive, or showcase your microblog/social media content? Check out this example from Mkultra.Monster.
  • Blogrolls are a great way to share your favorite sites from around the web. They are in their own right a federated social network. Reilly Spitzfaden just shared their blogroll!
  • Spencer Harston has a /books page, which is nothing more than a place for him to share the books he‚Äôs reading or has read. Neat!
  • Don‚Äôt just stand up a website, share what you stand for. Tracy Durnell has done this with their Guiding principles for my website post.
  • Wanna share a buncha stuff all at once? A ‚Äúmonthly recap‚Äù-style series is one way to go. Flamed Fury and The Shrediverse each have great examples of this.

Once you‚Äôre ready to take a break from building, why not do some (IndieWeb) surfin‚Äô? Three outstanding IndieWeb/Social Web-related aggregation/search clients I‚Äôd recommend you check out include Reeder, Tapestry & Surf. For discovery, I gotta turn you to my own list of IndieWeb search engines. Though two I‚Äôve seen pop up in my feeds recently include Blog of the .Day & blogroll.club, both awesome!

If all of that wasn‚Äôt enough for ya, check out some other cool stuff I‚Äôve come across this past week!

  • Good Internet Magazine (announcement from alexandra)
  • Dead Web Club
  • Plaintext World

Looking for your next writing challenge? Try the ‚ÄúBlog Questions Challenge‚Äù and answer these 8 questions‚Ä¶

  1. Why did you start blogging in the first place?
  2. What platform are you using to manage your blog and why did you choose it?
  3. Have you blogged on other platforms before?
  4. How do you write your posts? For example, in a local editing tool, or in a panel/dashboard that‚Äôs part of your blog?
  5. When do you feel most inspired to write?
  6. Do you publish immediately after writing, or do you let it simmer a bit as a draft?
  7. What‚Äôs your favourite post on your blog?
  8. Any future plans for your blog? Maybe a redesign, a move to another platform, or adding a new feature?

Fediverse

What‚Äôs goin‚Äô on in the Fediverse? So much. The Fedi Wiki has announced the launch of The Fedi Forum, a place for people to ask questions about Fedi software (among other things). Fediverse Discovery Providers is a project that recently launched which looks to improve decentralized search and discovery across the network. This is sorely needed as it is one of the bigger pain points of using the Fediverse. Fireside Fedi is a new show with interviews of the folks who build on the Fediverse. If you‚Äôre using Lemmy (and you should), check out phtn.app, a cool front-end app for browsing the Threadiverse! The Fediverse may be small compared to its ‚Äúcompetitors‚Äù, but it‚Äôs anything but stagnant.

To succeed, does the Fediverse ultimately need to grow? @rolle doesn‚Äôt seem to think so - and I agree!

Here‚Äôs how I put it‚Ä¶

The Fediverse doesn‚Äôt need everyone - everyone needs the Fediverse.

So if you aren‚Äôt already here. What‚Äôs stoppin‚Äô ya? For many it seems, choosing an instance is one of the biggest hangups. Here‚Äôs a resource that can maybe help you choose the right instance. Or perhaps you‚Äôre on Bluesky and are happy there. Ok, that‚Äôs fair. But can you run a Bluesky instance on a router? On a car? On a phone? Can you have a handle on a .ARPA domain? What about a car? On the Fediverse, you can.

from @celesteh@lgbt.io
Bluesky users: For a mere $30 million USD, we can distribute Bluesky to one other node

Fedi users: I put an instance on my car!

üòÜ

Here‚Äôs some other neat stuff I‚Äôve discovered this past week‚Ä¶

  • Curated list of server apps with support for AP
  • A guide to implement ActivityPub in a static site
  • Migrate your Mastodon posts/content to a GoToSocial instance with masto gear solid

The Fediverse is important, and it‚Äôs not going anywhere. It may never be the biggest, but it doesn‚Äôt need to be. If you care about creating lasting social spaces, reading and sharing news and information without censorship or algorithmic tampering, you need to create a presence here.

Cybersecurity

Here‚Äôs a roundup of cool IndieSec blogs and posts I‚Äôve discovered this past week‚Ä¶

  • Malicious.pro
  • B√°lint Magyar
  • SUSCTL from JPRX.IO
  • Hell is Overconfident Developers Writing Encryption Code from soatok.blog
  • Kuberenetes security fundamentals: Networking
  • SLAP & FLOP
  • Beyond XSS
  • Accessing a Private Network via Wireguard from cascadiacrow
  • Your Private Wireguard Network From Scratch from taggart-tech

Interested in some other infosec roundups? Luke has his weekly cyberlights, and Tim has a weekly post packed with interesting links.

Thanks for reading! Time for me to get some coffee.

item.description:
Phew ü•µ, what a flurry. Made a ton of changes to the site. The home page now features a mixed feed of all of my posts, notes, logs and other content types. I‚Äôve also started a link blog to share cool links I come across. Finally, I‚Äôve figured out how to paginate a TON of stuff, to make some of my pages more performant (my Activity page is one good example of how pagination is making that page usable on mobile now).

With respect to my home page, I used to be kinda precious about only exposing my formal ‚Äúblog posts‚Äù, which are supposed to be longer-form, and in some undefinable way, ‚Äúbetter‚Äù than other things I write and publish on the site. Inspired by others in the Indieweb community, who proudly feature everything they write, I decided to try out the same. To distinguish between different content types, i‚Äôve added a splash of color with icons corresponding to different post types. I also hope it can call attention (for those who are interested) to all the other things I publish. For so long, I had these hidden away in pages you could find via my ‚Äúhamburger‚Äù menu, but you had to go exploring to really find most of it. And given the number of things I link to in that menu, I doubt many people had the patience or interest to really hunt down other things. So, here we are!

Let me know what ya think! I‚Äôm still tinkering around with the format, theme and other general aesthetics of the site and various pages, but I like it well enough at this point.

item.description:
I have a lot of different points-of-presence on the Fediverse - my ‚Äúmain‚Äù Mastodon account, this GoToSocial account, another ‚Äúalt‚Äù Masto account, a Lemmy account, my new Pixelfed account, and many more actually.

My story isn‚Äôt unique, a lot of people who have embraced the wider Fediverse have accounts for different services and I‚Äôve seen a lot of those same people asking for a way to have a ‚Äúsingular‚Äù identity (I actually wrote about this here). But since that isn‚Äôt a thing, I‚Äôve seen another interesting thing happen, at least with my own fedi usage/accounts. My central, ‚Äúmain‚Äù account has become what I boost all of my other accounts content from. The ‚Äúmain‚Äù account has the majority of my ‚Äúfollowers‚Äù (yuck - always dislike that term), so when I post something from one of my satellite accounts, the main one can just boost it.

It‚Äôs working-ish for me so far I think.

This let‚Äôs me post things on each respective service, which goes out to just the followers of the satellite accounts themselves, and if I choose, I can boost from my ‚Äúmain‚Äù account so it can receive the full reach of the main account.

item.title: Fundraising Pixelfed vs Free Our Feeds

shark:summary.p: Not to beat this into the ground, but I think it‚Äôs an interesting side-by-side comparison. Let‚Äôs look at the fundraising efforts for Pixelfed and Free Our Feeds‚Ä¶

item.description:
Not to beat this into the ground, but I think it‚Äôs an interesting side-by-side comparison. Let‚Äôs look at the fundraising efforts for Pixelfed and Free Our Feeds‚Ä¶

  • Pixelfed: They wanted to raise ~35k, blew through this very reasonable goal in less than a day, and have no raised nearly ~60k. This is an effort to continue improving what is already an existing platform with 100s of thousands of active users.

  • FreeOurFeeds: They want to raise (to start) 4 million dollars, and after 10 days, have only raised ~75k. This effort is to replicate the entirety of Bluesky‚Äôs infrastructure to prove that it can be decentralized.

There‚Äôs a lot you can try to pull from this. One, Pixelfed is a real thing. You can go get the app right now and use it. It works well! It connects to other stuff on the Fediverse, it‚Äôs got actual users, etc‚Ä¶ The fundraising goal isn‚Äôt ridiculous or exorbitant, it‚Äôs practical. The Kickstarter description is VERY comprehensive, explaining everything they‚Äôve done, and everything they want to do. There‚Äôs no emphasis on Daniel as some tech visionary or thought leader, it‚Äôs just down to Earth.

Contrast that with Free Our Feeds - Light on details, grossly insistent on telling me all the ‚Äúadvisors‚Äù titles, weird site design, and all in support of something that is entirely unproven.

It‚Äôs painfully evident, just in the fundraising alone that FoF is not substantive, and is not attracting meaningful interest. Or maybe FoF should set their sights a bit lower. Build something small to start proving out their claims, demonstrate this to the public and then ask to raise money, similar to what the Pixelfed team has done.

But what do I know‚Ä¶

item.title: Bluesky, ATProtocol, Free Our Feeds: Hope abounds, but very little is proven

shark:summary.p: Here we go again‚Ä¶ Mike Masnick just posted his writeup titled ‚ÄúHow ATProtocol Encourages Competition, Resists Evil Billionaires, Lock-In & Enshittification‚Äù, and as usual, I‚Äôve got some thoughts‚Ä¶

item.description:
Here we go again‚Ä¶ Mike Masnick just posted his writeup titled ‚ÄúHow ATProtocol Encourages Competition, Resists Evil Billionaires, Lock-In & Enshittification‚Äù, and as usual, I‚Äôve got some thoughts‚Ä¶

Note: First, I want to preface this by saying that I‚Äôm no ATproto expert, or an expert on social media protocols in general. Similarly, I‚Äôm not an expert on business, or VC funding or an enshittification scholar. I‚Äôm just a nerd who cares way too much about these things so I feel compelled to share my thoughts‚Ä¶ here we go‚Ä¶

Alright, so Mike likes Bluesky. Duh! He‚Äôs on the board of Bluesky. He very willingly discloses this, and that‚Äôs important. Because there is definitely bias. We all have biases. I‚Äôm not on the board of anything, but I ‚Äúmain‚Äù the Fediverse, and as such also have some innate bias to be sure about why this place is better, blah blah blah. Ok, disclosures out of the way now‚Ä¶

Let me sum up Mike‚Äôs reasoning for why Bluesky (or ATproto specifically) is super great, billionaire resistant, enshittification resistant, etc‚Ä¶

  1. ATproto is an ‚Äúopen protocol‚Äù, i.e. someone else can take it, and use it to stand up another Bluesky. For him, this means a billionaire is less likely to try and capture Bluesky, because another one could spawn up causing the billionaire to have to whack-a-mole these networks‚Ä¶

  2. Free Our Feeds (See 1). Mike see‚Äôs ‚ÄúFoF‚Äù as proof that ATproto works. That another bluesky will be created, and by extrapolation, even more will come up beyond this initial effort.

  3. Bluesky won‚Äôt enshittify because competing Bsky networks exist. (Well first, no they don‚Äôt. They might, if the FoF thing works out.)

  4. Mike also makes a lot of assumptions around people hosting their own PDS‚Äôs (something a very small fraction of people will actually do) and about their willingness to switch Bluesky providers, or ‚Äútake the fire exit‚Äù (to use Doctorow‚Äôs terminology).

Let‚Äôs poke-a the holes, yeah?

  1. Alright, ATProto looks open enough, the docs are right here!. Again, I‚Äôm no expert, and have spent no time standing up any aspect of the Bluesky network or implementing ATproto in any way, but the docs seem comprehensive and theres write-ups out there of people standing up just about all of the infra required to replicate Bluesky, at least in some limited fashion. As of 11/24, there was this ONE holdout (based on this blog) where it seemed like you couldn‚Äôt yet really self-host your own AppView. Maybe this has been resolved by now? But let‚Äôs assume you CAN stand up every bit of Bluesky (if you have the money - we‚Äôll cover that later), does this mean someone will? I mean ‚ÄúFree Our Feeds‚Äù is going to try to, but that‚Äôs just one other person. There‚Äôs close to 30 million users, so there‚Äôs definitely non-trivial interest in Bluesky and maybe in the underlying protocol, but how can we be so sure that if the main Bluesky were to go down, that anyone would care enough to keep standing up more instances of it? Sure it‚Äôs open, but do people care enough? You can point to FoF as proof that someone cares enough to do it, but you need more than just one replica of Bluesky to be billionaire-resistant. Also, I‚Äôll remind you that FoF is experimental. No one has actually done what they are trying to do. Sure parts of the network have been replicated, but to build a full-on, interconnected bsky clone and get people to move over to it? Unproven.

  2. Free Our Feeds. I‚Äôve covered the FoF thing extensively here. Basically, building a Bluesky clone for 4 million dollars, or 30 million dollars or w/e proves nothing to me. That alone is not enough to outmaneuver a hungry billionaire. If Musk can buy Twitter for 44 Billion, he can absolutely snatch up like 10 Bluesky instances without breaking a sweat.

  3. On enshittification. I think some level of enshittification is inevitable for Bluesky. Which isn‚Äôt to say it will make the service unusable, or that it will become ‚Äúbad‚Äù because of it. The simple fact is that Bluesky needs to monetize. They have to because they took VC money. right? This seems like a simple truth, but happy to be explained why that isn‚Äôt the case. So yeah, how will they monetize? They don‚Äôt want to paywall the entire service, that will kill the open-ness and definitely cause them to lose active users. SO they need to paywall power-user stuff? Ok, that‚Äôs not going to get VC-level returns. What else? Sell domain names? Yeah, not going to cut it either. I dont know what they‚Äôre going to do. Mike has said, (and he has inside knowledge) that they are working on some ideas. I hope he‚Äôs right. But if the end result is paywalling actual useful features, or doing ads, or selling peoples data, then the service is enshittifying. Which again, doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs bad, and doesn‚Äôt mean that it will become something most people don‚Äôt wanna use. Only that compromises had to be made, so that the VCs could see their returns. Think about it though, if there was some magical way to monetize and make MILLIONS, without doing ads (or similar), wouldn‚Äôt someone have done it? He says, they won‚Äôt enshittify, because there are competing services people will run to. Like where? To FoF? They don‚Äôt even exist yet, and even if they did, they are also battling the enshittification demons. The Fediverse? Lol. If people wanted to go there, they‚Äôd be there. Back to X? Threads? C‚Äômon. Sure, these other networks might prevent them from going FULL-ON enshittifiy mode, but it‚Äôs just a game of, can we make our platform just a LITTLE LESS awful than any other.

  4. Let me get to the real reason why none of this matters. The costs of moving. People DO. NOT. WANT. TO. MOVE. They just don‚Äôt. If Bluesky enshittifies, a lot of people just won‚Äôt go. I mean look at X. So many have stayed because it‚Äôs just too much of a hassle to sign up for ANOTHER thing, and rebuild. Now before you say, ‚Äúbut AT is open protocol! I can move my followers, I can host my own PDS! blah blah‚Äù. Stop. Most people aren‚Äôt going to host their own PDS. So they‚Äôre not migrating their posts elsewhere. More importantly, let‚Äôs talk about followers. People don‚Äôt want to lose their communities, their followers, their friends. I don‚Äôt know exactly how ATproto handles moving followers, but the idea is that it can be done. So if Bsky main goes to shit, FoF is now there, people can just sign up there, move their followers over. Great right? Problem solved? No. For one, not everyone‚Äôs going to do that. Remember, people HATE moving. Ok, so now you have another fracturing event. Half of your friends are on Bsky main, and you and the other half of your friends have moved to FoF Bsky. No problem right? ATproto is meant to communicate between instances. Sure‚Ä¶ but this ASSUMES that the main Bsky is being a good citizen and allowing this communication right? Maybe for those who have opted to host their own PDS‚Äôs you can have the FoF relay scoop your posts, but for everyone on the main Bsky PDS (which again, is most people), you might not be so lucky.

You see, we on the Fediverse know these things. People get confused when there is more than one instance, people get confused when Mastodon instance 1 can communicate with Mastodon instance 2, but they have different names, different cultures, different features. They just don‚Äôt grok it. But the larger network of ATproto-enabled bsky instances have to contend with instances being adversarial. How will they do this? In the Fedi world, you just defederate and move on. But in a world where there‚Äôs only two bsky instances (or three or 4 or whatever), each hosting an equal portion of the entire network, you can‚Äôt do this without handicapping the entire network. So in a scenario where a billionaire takes over Bsky main, shuts off communication with the second Bsky instance, and becomes adversarial (not allowing follower moves? not sure if that‚Äôs possible), keeps people from getting their content, etc‚Ä¶ then what? There‚Äôs just not enough resiliency in the model.

Finally, I want to touch on some of his closing thoughts. He makes a lot of statements about how FoF is ‚Äúproof‚Äù that this is possible, and that when successful it will ‚Äúbring us back towards the original promise of the open web where users are in control, rather than giant companies‚Äù, neither of which makes sense to me. For one, FoF hasn‚Äôt proved anything. They want to raise 4 million to start and haven‚Äôt even hit 100k. They haven‚Äôt proven it will work, they haven‚Äôt even proven that people care about decentralization enough to fund a second instance (spoiler, people don‚Äôt care about decentralization, if they did they‚Äôd go where its already been proven). Second, he says bluesky, or ATproto puts the users in control, not companies. Does it though? Users don‚Äôt run these platforms. They can‚Äôt afford to. FoF needs 4-30 million to do it, and again, they haven‚Äôt yet.

With Bluesky, we are not in control. Maybe, just maybe you can make a convincing argument that it can be billionaire-resistant, but it sure isn‚Äôt something that then people own. It takes big money to run these instances, and the people don‚Äôt have big money. Corporate interests do. That‚Äôs why Bluesky needs VC. The Fediverse on the other hand doesn‚Äôt. It‚Äôs for the people, by the people, funded by the people. It‚Äôs a proven solution. I want to end this by saying that I don‚Äôt want to see Bluesky fail. I want to see the protocol evolve. I want to see it compete with ActivityPub, each pushing each other forward. I want to see FoF succeed and for another real decentralized player to come into form. I want things to be billionaire proof. I just don‚Äôt think this is it.

When I first downloaded the app and got into the Beta, I admit I wasn‚Äôt sure what the app would do for me that my already-well-curated Fediverse timelines wasn‚Äôt doing. item.description:
The Surf app from Flipboard (currently in Beta) is actually pretty cool / powerful for certain types of feeds. I would describe Surf as, an app for the Social Web that let‚Äôs you build and share custom feeds. So what does this mean in practice? The Surf about page is a little light on detail, but has gobs of style. When I first downloaded the app and got into the Beta, I admit I wasn‚Äôt sure what the app would do for me that my already-well-curated Fediverse timelines wasn‚Äôt doing. But then, I built my first custom feed. From there, I started to see the potential‚Ä¶

Surfing Shellsharks

To test out Surf, I first tried creating a simple feed pulling all of my Shellsharks-related things from across the ‚ÄúSocial Web‚Äù together. I was able to add Sources for my RSS feeds, my Podcast, my Bluesky profile, my Threads profile, my various Fediverse accounts and even posts that were ‚Äúabout‚Äù or matched the term ‚Äúshellsharks‚Äù. Interesting! It‚Äôs easy enough to create a ‚Äúlist‚Äù in a given Fediverse client that can capture most of these things (e.g. my Fedi accounts, Bsky, Threads, RSS feeds, etc‚Ä¶) but not all of them. Pulling in posts that match certain search criteria is an added layer of discovery for me. It also treats Bluesky and Threads and other non-Fedi-native content as first-party content within the Surf app itself, bundled in a pleasing, swipable, card-style view, allowing me to flick through posts that match my source material.

OK, well that looks cool, and I‚Äôll definitely go to it to check in on myself, but what else can I [do with Surf](#benefits-of-a-social-web-browser-and-feed-builder?

Benefits of a Social Web Browser and Feed Builder

So what can Surf do beyond building eye-pleasing lists of Fediverse accounts and hashtags? Let‚Äôs talk about it.

The first obvious answer is sharing. There‚Äôs no easy way to create and then share lists of Fediverse accounts. We saw this when Bluesky unveiled their ‚ÄúStarter Packs‚Äù and the Fediverse tried to mimic it, and it‚Äôs true to this day. The Fediverse‚Äôs non-algorithmic way of life means we rely mainly on self-curating and network-related-boosting. Without robust list sharing features, we‚Äôve never really had an easy way to share our curated lists, but Surf tries to make this easier. I have several custom feeds now that you can add (if and when you get the Surf app). Since you log in to Surf with your Fedi account, you can also interact with and follow things directly from the app!

Another thing I like about the Surf model is the ability to follow feeds or accounts in a more, casual manner. Everything I follow in my regular Fediverse timeline is something I want to see. I want to read what my follows post and potentially interact with those things. I am a timeline completionist in this way. But there are times I want to casually scroll, to be entertained, or informed or to discover new things I want to follow. Custom feeds via Surf give me the ability to peruse things in a non-commital way. For example, to do something similar in Mastodon, I would need to A. follow an account/hashtag, B. add that account/tag to a list, and then optionally C. decide whether I want to remove what‚Äôs in that list from my timeline. This forces me to follow things I might be interested in looking at from time to time, but not actually following, and it forces me to make a decision on how to bisect my main timeline, which is not something I want to do. In short, I don‚Äôt like Mastodon lists, but I like what I can do with Surf.

Let‚Äôs talk about content diversity. Within the Fediverse, I can curate a list or feed of a lot of things. Micro-blogs, pictures, videos, podcasts, forum posts, and more. The beauty of the Fediverse is in it‚Äôs diversity. But the Fediverse, as large as it is, is still only a subset of an even wider ‚ÄúSocial Web‚Äù. What Surf let‚Äôs me do, that you can‚Äôt exactly do within a traditional Fediverse client, is build a feed that has even more types of things - generic keyword searches, YouTube videos, podcasts, native (not-bridged) Bluesky profiles, and I suspect more in the future.

The final benefit (at least that I‚Äôve discovered thus far), is the opportunity for improved search. At the bottom of the Surf app is a text box that says ‚ÄúSurf the social web‚Äù, and it seems to bring back a lot of good results! Far better than what I can get on my single-user instance, and I suspect better than most people can get even on larger, mid-sized instances. I don‚Äôt know a lot about how this search works under the hood, but it‚Äôs already an improvement over what I have.

This is just a beta, so there‚Äôs lots of room to iron kinks out and add even more types of content, and ways to further tailor feeds. I‚Äôm looking forward to

My Custom Surf Feeds

If you‚Äôre in the beta, feel free to check all of my custom feeds out! Note: They are all a work in progress.

  • Shellsharks feed: Just a feed which aggregates my various blog RSS feeds, Fedi accounts, podcast and Bluesky
  • Fedi Artists feed: All my favorite artists from the Fediverse (inspired by this. )
  • IndieSec feed: A curated list of high signal-to-noise infosec/cybersecurity researchers and accounts
  • Fedbuilds and Builders feed: A list of accounts for Fediverse platforms and the builders behind them
  • Reality: a news feed: Independent / trust-worthy news. An attempt to capture ‚Äúreality‚Äù, not spin

If you‚Äôre interested in Surf, go check it out!

I‚Äôm going to go play around with it more and make some more feeds! Shoutout to @mike!

Appendices

Feature Requests

As I‚Äôm beta-testing the app, I‚Äôm documenting some features I‚Äôd like to see in-app here‚Ä¶

  • I‚Äôd like a way to just punch in an RSS endpoint and have that load via the search box
  • As someone who has multiple Fedi presences, I‚Äôd like to be able to go multi-account within the Surf app
  • Maybe notifications for what/when things are added/changed in a feed you are subscribed to
  • More ways to programatically customize things in custom feeds

Bugs

Also, as I‚Äôm beta testing the app, I‚Äôm going to document some bugs I‚Äôve encountered here‚Ä¶

  • Some general slowness loading the app, loading in to a custom feed, etc‚Ä¶
  • I can‚Äôt set the ‚ÄúTile Image‚Äù to ‚ÄúAlways use uploaded photo‚Äù in Feed/Cover Settings

item.title: Legal & regulatory threats to the Fediverse

shark:summary.p: In a recent post, I made the case for why the Fediverse, with it‚Äôs many thousands of instances would be impractical for billionaires to ‚Äòtake down‚Äô, in the same way that billionaires have successfully bought-out, or otherwise taken down other centralized social media/news platforms. This I think is true, in terms of the Fediverse‚Äôs resiliency to the power of just money being thrown, but vulnerability remains. Specifically, I am concerned about recent government regulation that has already proven to be effective in closing down Fediverse instances and deterring others from even spinning up an instance.

item.description:
In a recent post, I made the case for why the Fediverse, with it‚Äôs many thousands of instances would be impractical for billionaires to ‚Äòtake down‚Äô, in the same way that billionaires have successfully bought-out, or otherwise taken down other centralized social media/news platforms. This I think is true, in terms of the Fediverse‚Äôs resiliency to the power of just money being thrown, but vulnerability remains. Specifically, I am concerned about recent government regulation that has already proven to be effective in closing down Fediverse instances and deterring others from even spinning up an instance.

I‚Äôm no legal professional, so excuse me if I say anything that is wrong or doesn‚Äôt make sense. Anecdotally, I‚Äôve seen a bunch of posts across the Fediverse about how they are closing down an instance thanks to the UK‚Äôs Online Safety Act (2023). Similarly, it seems like the US bill (KOSA) could have similar effects? From what I understand, there is some new liability if your server hosts certain content and given how many Fediverse servers operate, caching content locally from other servers, there introduces a vulnerability by which a malicious actor could spam the Fediverse with something ‚Äúbad‚Äù/illegal which would then be stored/cached across a large swath of the Fediverse which could expose these instance admins to legal liability.

Not good. And as someone who runs an instance themselves, I certainly don‚Äôt want to open myself up to legal attack / prosecution just because some A-hole out there decides to spam me with illegal pictures or w/e.

So my question to the Fediverse, and to those that build the platforms we use here is, how can we re-architect the platforms and protocols to better protect ourselves? What do instance admins need to know about this threat? Someone smarter than me, please weigh in! üòÖ

#askfedi #legal #fediverse
